saves us car and insurance payments your husband sounds like really demanding jerk the reason he feels like you guys are business partners is because he is treating you like an employee and not wife if he wants the house kept certain way then he can take care of it if he wants your son cared for in such particular fashion then he can do it while you go back to work reading through this and it families we are all in this parenting thing together know you re asking for different advice but your husband sounds incredibly manipulative and potentially emotionally abusive am currently sahm for few more weeks to 12 week old and it is not as easy as he thinks it is no matter what the age regardless of how many hours of sleep you bag in 24 hour period it not the pre kid sleep you used to enjoy furthermore there is nothing wrong with having your kid entertain himself while you catch up on housework provided you check in to make sure kid is alive it encouraged to let kids play on their own let my 12 week old play by himself so he can study things without me constantly distracting him year old should be more than capable of entertaining himself anyway sorry you re getting crap from your husband for what sounds like totally normal day and life we all go through ups and downs not getting motivational notes from you is clearly affecting him it seems like fairly simple thing to start back up again to make him feel loved maybe write out week worth on the weekend when your husband is home and watching lo my other advice is to read the love languages or just visit the website and each of you take the test it helps you better understand what each of you needs from the other to feel loved my dh and are both primarily acts of service which means we feel loved when the other one does something for us like will make him breakfast and get him coffee on weekend mornings used to do it before lo but have yet to get back on that schedule best of luck to you both your husband yes there is some risk to kids when they climb and play but they re flexible and resilient and most bumps do even bother them the benefits of free play far outweigh the few risks children develop motor skills and coordination faster and more proficiently they get the many health benefits of being active and they actually learn better once they re at school age the other issue is that without learning how to balance and without building strength from climbing and playing your son is lot more likely to injure himself when he does get chance to climb it was hard but as my son got into toddler age had to stop myself from rushing over every time he tried to climb onto the couch instead put body cushion along the couch and just stood back he fell on the cushion couple times and missed updates over whether things are getting better gt went into our marriage knowing he was going to be the head of the family you know that the whole head of the family thing is an outdated idea people in the family can have different roles like breadwinner and housekeeper but the term head of the family implies that he in charge of you that not the way it should be the breadwinner in our family and my husband is the housekeeper but our relationship is partnership not the head of him he helps me out when ve had bad time at work and help him out when our daughter has been handful all day your relationship will serve as model for your son perhaps the way you ve represented your husband to us is making him look worse than he is but if not you should think about what lessons he going to be gt like having someone in charge and making decisions that understandable but if you completely hand the keys of your life over to another person you may not like the direction he she takes you in really recommend that you try to stand up for yourself and insist on your marriage being an equal partnership it okay to cede control when something is going on that you do feel like you know how to handle or you do have an opinion on but you should make it clear to your husband that when you do have an opinion that *it matters* and that he needs to listen to you you also need to try to trust your gut it seems clear from your posts that you are with your son much much more than your husband when it comes to child raising *you* should be the head of that department *you* are the one who is with your son all day *you* see how he interacts with his environment and how he is developing *you* should be the one who judges whether it safe to leave him alone for bit or whether he deal well with having stranger watch him for few hours your husband should certainly feel welcome to voice his opinions and you should take them into account but he should not be *telling* you what to do with your son while he at work and he should not be making you feel bad about what you re doing if your son tends to be happy and well adjusted know you say you do know how to make decisions for your son but trust your gut your mother instinct is strong learned with my daughter that if you ask question about child rearing you will get hundred different responses many of which will be directly contradicting each other learned to go with my gut with what felt right they tell you to make sure to tell you pediatrician if you feel anything is right with your child because you re with the child all day and the pediatrician is only with the child for few minutes lot of problems are noticed by the parents even though they do have medical degree and if they do speak up to the pediatrician then serious problems can go undiagnosed the same goes for normal parenting too even though you do have parenting degree you can usually tell when something is not right with your child since you re with him all day learn to trust yourself for example if your husband tells you you should turn your back on your child or leave him unsupervised for few minutes your gut tells you this is okay otherwise you would have done it it okay to trust that instinct your husband does see your son as much as you do he may not realize how capable your son is of entertaining himself and judging his own safety assuming the space is safe of course something ve been thinking about you said in another post somewhere that you only feel stressed when your husband is home have you told him this my husband and have very open policy if one of us does something that the other one is uncomfortable with we speak up it does matter how small the issue or how justified we feel about it we both know that if we keep issues bottled up inside it only makes things worse we ve had some tear filled conversations like that but once it over and we both understand how the other feels there freedom there at worst we do have to keep dancing around the issue and at best one or both of us changes our behavior so that the problem goes away or is at least lessened if you get problems out in the open it may start with hurt feelings anger and frustration but that the first step to solution think of it as cauterizing wound you need to endure that pain in order to heal if you have problem confronting him write down your feelings and give him the note or send him an email make sure you talk about how his actions make you feel try to acknowledge his point of view if you can but do compromise your own position for instance you can say you know he only concerned for you son and you know he very stressed with his job currently but his constant criticism of how you handle what is essentially your job is causing you stress and pain maybe tell him you re willing to listen to his advice but that you really appreciate it if he tone it down so that it *constructive* criticism and not just criticism maybe even ask that if he wants motivational speeches and support in his work you like the same because raising kid and keeping up household is as much work as what he doing everyone likes being told they re doing good job once and while and if all you hear from loved one is criticism it going to hurt be ready to talk about the letter after you ve given it to him maybe after he had some time to digest it at some point you have to do these things face to face though letter to start it off makes it easier to establish your position without giving him an opportunity to interrupt with his own point of view you both should hear *all* of what the other has to say first and then you can discuss it he may not realize what he putting you through emotionally he may be so caught up in his own work problems and the financial problems of the household that he has stopped to think what his words have been doing to you edit typo
